In a monoid, the empty product is defined as the unit element, i.e., $\prod_{i=1}^{0} a_{i} := e$, where $e$ is the unit element.

For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
The residue class module M/N of an A-module M by a submodule N is defined analogously to the quotient space in vector spaces, where M/N consists of the cosets of N in M.
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
An extension $K_{r} / K$ is Galois if it is both normal and separable.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A Galois extension is a field extension that is both normal and separable. Therefore, the concept of a Galois extension depends on the definition of a normal field extension.
A group is a set equipped with an associative binary operation, an identity element, and inverses for every element. The Klein Four-Group is a specific example of a group.
